headline: At This Hour
subHeadline: Alex Murdaugh Cross-Examined In His Murder Trial. Aired 11- 11:30a ET

utterances.speaker: KATE BOLDUAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Hello everyone. Thank you so much for being here. I'm Kate Bolduan. At this hour, we're going to take you back to South Carolina where we have been watching a second day of Alex Murdaugh on the stand testifying in his own defense. It's also a second day of cross examination in his double murder trial. The chief prosecutor really getting into it today and grilling Murdaugh about his drug addiction and his alleged financial crimes and long list of lies. Let's get back into the courtroom right now.

utterances.speaker: ALEX MURDAUGH, MURDER DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: I don't -- did I have a conversation with Paul about cash?

utterances.speaker: CREIGHTON WATERS, PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: Yes. That you talked to him about cash and some problem with his tale prior to going down there? Did you have any knowledge of that prior to going down there?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure. As I sit here today, I don't recall that, but I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: When you first arrived in the golf cart, where did you pull up to?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I pulled up right where Maggie was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Which is where?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: She was standing in a spot where she could see in between chicken coop and the storage room of the kennels, where the dogs were back up in those planted pines behind the kennels to the left of the chicken coop.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And what did you do after that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I went back to the house.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No, I mean, did you pulled up, you get out of the golf cart?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, when I pulled up, I stayed on the golf cart.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You stayed on the golf cart. How long did you stay on the golf cart? MURDAUGH

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The entire time?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I got off to take the chicken from Bubba.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, so how long were you down there before you took the chicken off to Bubba?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Very short time.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Like what?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: A couple of minutes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And what were you doing during the couple of minutes before you got over there to deal with Bubba?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Talking to Mags.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, and what did you all talk about?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't remember?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir. I do know that Maggie was very concerned about Paul-Paul. And --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You remember a lot of detail about all these new facts, but you don't remember what you talked about?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't remember the exact details of what we talked about. I believe that at that time, we may have talked about Paul-Paul, but I'm not certain.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Were you withdrawing at this time?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: At this time, no, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You weren't withdrawing at all?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No. I mean, I would only withdraw when I didn't have pills.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Then you're saying you had pills?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Down there for a couple of minutes, I think you've said now before you get off the golf cart.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: About, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And where do you go at that point?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I take the chicken from Bubba. WATERS

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, Bubba is, you know, Bubba's come out there with this chicken. I mean, he's showing us, hey, I caught this chicken, and I take the chicken from Bubba.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did Bubba came up by the golf cart?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He came up by the golf cart and then he came up to Maggie and I, which I was on the golf cart. She's by the golf cart. I mean he's not coming to the golf cart, but he's coming to us.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Is this during the kennel video or is this after the kennel video?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, no, you hear Maggie say he's got a chicken. That's what she's talking about, is Bubba caught a chicken.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, all right. So is the kennel video still going on before you go get the chicken? I mean, you've heard it correct? You've heard it in this courtroom?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know exactly. I don't know exactly. But in close timing to Bubba coming out of those woods with the chicken, I got up and took the chicken from him.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Let me ask you this. Were the dogs barking and carrying on or going out into the woods or acting like they sent somebody was around that they didn't know?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Were the dogs acting like there was somebody around it, they didn't know?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, like dogs do.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: No, they weren't.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: There was nobody around that the dogs didn't know.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: There was nobody else around --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, good.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: -- for them to sense.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You've heard the kennel video. Would you agree with me that it lasts for about 50 seconds?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I agree with that. WATERS

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I do agree with that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you have the chicken out of Bubba's mouth at the end of the kennel video, or did it take longer than that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You know, I can't remember exactly when in the video he came up with the chicken, but I would have had the chicken out of his mouth within 10, 15 seconds of Maggie saying he's got a chicken.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And so then what did you do?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I put the chicken up.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. How long did that take? Did you get out of the golf cart to do that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And you had to go walk to where it was?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, yes, I mean, a few feet, but I did that, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, so how long did that take? We're at 8

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Seconds.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Just seconds? All right. And what did you do after that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Got back on the golf cart.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And what did you do after that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I left.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You left. Just jumped on the golf cart and left.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, that's what I was getting ready to say. Did I get on the golf cart and leave that second? Probably not. But did I get on the golf cart and leave very quickly after that? I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Yes, I think you testified yesterday, I got out of there.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Why'd you get out of there so quick, Mr. Murdaugh?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Because it was chaotic, it was hot, and I was getting ready to do exactly what I didn't want to do.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You're getting ready to do what you didn't want to do?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct. WATERS

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I was getting ready to sweat. I was getting ready to work. I went back to the air conditioner.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: So did you say goodbye, according to your new story?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Did I say goodbye?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Did you talk to them at all, or did you just get the chicken put on there, jump on there and just take off?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, I wouldn't have just gone off. I mean, I would have said, I'm leaving.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Did I say goodbye? Bye.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And again, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean there would have been some, you know, there would have been some exchange. I'm not staying here.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What was that exchange? I mean, you've had such a photographic memory about these new stories. What happened here?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: There's not. I can't tell you the exact words.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You don't remember your conversation after you put that chicken up? Did you all talk about the chicken?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think we did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you talk with Paul about cash's tale?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: After the chicken?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I know I didn't do that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you tell Maggie, I'm going to go check on him?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: At that point? No, I don't think I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you tell Maggie, oh, let's hide out here if I could go back?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I certainly would have said something to that effect.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So unlike everything else with the new story, you just can't recall what that would have been?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I mean you're making that categorization. I think there's other things about that I can't remember. But if the question is, can I remember exactly what words I used when I gave Maggie some salutation when I'm leaving? I can't tell you what those were, but it would have been something to the effect of I'm leaving.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. OK. But you would concede that there was at least some conversation that you wouldn't have just put the chicken on there and jump, ran back to the golf cart and taken off, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Without talking to Maggie? I would have never done that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. All right, well, let's, you know, you want to say a minute? Does that sound about right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: A minute for what?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: To have just whatever interaction it took for you to then, according to your new story, drive back to --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir. It wouldn't have taken me a minute. It would have been -- it would have said -- it would have been, I'm leaving. I'll see you in a minute.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK. So 30 seconds?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't think it would have taken 30 seconds, but I mean, I'm fine with you using whatever time you want to apply, but I don't think it wouldn't taken long.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'm just asking about real life here and how people interact with one another, Mr. Murdaugh. I mean, so what you're telling this jury, I call you're fuzzy on these kind of details is that you jetted down there. You dealt with the chicken and jetted right back?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, well, if it's about 8

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Maybe. I mean, I don't think it was that long, but maybe. Sure.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, so.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: But I don't think it was that long. I mean exactly what I thought was going to be going on at that kennel, why I didn't want to go there to begin with is exactly what was going on.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, well, I get that.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And I left.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Are these also convenient facts in your new story that have to fit with the timeline now that evidence has been thrown in your face?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Does that sound like real life to you, that you jet down there and jet back, Mr. Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters, as I just told you, I didn't get on my golf cart and jet down there. I didn't jet back.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The reason why you have to be fuzzy about these details --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- just answer before another question is presented.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. Just a moment --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm answering your question.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Are you responding to the last question?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. I'm responding to your question. And you're using words that I'm not using. And that's your categorization.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'm entitled to ask my questions to you, sir?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And I'm going to answer them. All I'm saying is I'm taking issue with the manner in which you're changing what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: So you disagree this is a new story? You disagree with that characterization?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is the first time that this is being told openly.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you disagree to my characterization that you've got a photographic memory about the details that have to fit now that these facts, but you're fuzzy on the other stuff that complicates that. You disagree with that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I do disagree with that. I think that I have a good memory about a lot of things on this.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How about this? We got the kennel at the video ending at 8

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: The Kennel video ended at 8

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And 45 seconds.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not 8

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I think it was sooner than that but it could have been.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, that's 60 seconds and 75 seconds, correct? After it ends.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If it ends at 8

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You characterize it yesterday as I got out of there, right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That is exactly what I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So if we're at 8

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Approximately.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, and when you got back to the house, where did you park the golf cart?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Same place I'd gotten it from, right where Mark Ball testified that it was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, and what door did you go in?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I would have gone in the front door.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And if you left around 8

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If I left at 8

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did go inside and the T.V. was on.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK. And you laid down, is that right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, before you said you've been napping for an hour or so or napping that entire time and now you lay down on the couch?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And maybe dose for a second?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Maybe.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: According to your new story. How long did you dose?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If I dosed, extremely short time.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Extremely short time. Because you would agree with me that at 9

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I agree that according to that data, my phone's recording steps at whatever time it is, 9

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I would have gone straight to the couch probably. I may have gone by the sink or, you know, I may have gotten a spit cup, but it would have been basically straight to the couch.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Straight to the couch?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you're telling this jury that's what happened and you were back at the house at 8

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, your number is 8

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you go anywhere else in the house?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters, I can't tell you specifically about that. I don't think so, but I may have.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you have that 10 blackout in a 12 gage shotgun on that golf cart when you drove down there?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You didn't?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you see them when you were down there?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No. WATERS

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I did not.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You didn't? Did you tell law enforcement that you thought you heard them pull up, didn't you tell law enforcement that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did think they had pulled up.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, so that was that you did think that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So now you're saying there was a car pulling up?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You didn't testify to that yesterday, did you, in your new version of events that --?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I don't -- Mr. Waters, I don't believe there was a car pulling up.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK, but that's what you told law enforcement, didn't you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I told law enforcement that I thought they had pulled up.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK. All right, but you're saying you couldn't hear blackout shots supposedly. But you could hear that, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I didn't say I couldn't hear blackout shots, but I'm saying that I thought when I got up from taking a nap, if I took a nap, but when I got up from laying down, as I was getting ready to go to my mom's, there was a point in time where I thought Maggie and Paul had come back.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK. You also told him that you thought you heard a wildcat and maybe it was a person or something like that as well?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, that's not what I said.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What did you say then?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I said when I went outside that there's a house cat that's gone wild and he hangs around, he goes from hanging around the shop, goes from hanging around the house, different times, you might, and there'll be times you don't see him. And he had been around the house. When I went outside, I believe that cat was over there.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK. And you made a point in mentioning that to law enforcement?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I never thought it was a person.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, but you made a point in mentioning that to law enforcement, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: In the course of discussing it, I did tell them that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: But you never told them all this new story that you've constructed in light of this trial, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did not tell them that I went to the kennel. I lied about that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And at the same time, you also looked at this jury and tried to tell them that you had been cooperative in this investigation?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Other than lying to them about going to the kennel, I was cooperative in every aspect of this investigation.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Very cooperative. Except maybe the most important fact of all, that you were at the murder scene with the victims' just minutes before they died, right?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did not tell them that I went to the kennel.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We'll take a break at this time for about 15 minutes talking to the jury. Please go to the jury room. Please not discuss the case.

utterances.speaker: JEAN CASAREZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: What we have just been listening to, the timeline, this is the pivotal timeline. It is so important because it will be a jury question of fact when they get in there to deliberate. What we just heard was that the kennel video began at 8We just learned it ends at 8:45.45. Alex Murdaugh just admitted not only that he was down there, but he admitted that maybe he didn't leave the area on the golf cart right at the kennel until about 8:47, and then went about two minutes to get back to the house. We know from previous testimony that at 8:49, Maggie and Paul's phones lock forever. They never turn them on again. The prosecutor is using this, we've heard this in the trial as the time of death, the estimated time of death, because obviously you can't turn your phone back on. Now, the defense is going to argue strongly against that because they were busy down there, they were working with the dogs and the chickens and everything. So just because they're not using their phones doesn't mean that's when they were murdered. But now there's something else with this timeline. We know because of the OnStar data that at 9:07, Alex Murdaugh was in his car going down the driveway to go visit his mother. So you look at that very small timeline, 8:49, when the phone stopped, let's say that's when he murdered them. You've got a short duration of time before 9:07, right? That's 13 minutes, give or take, right? You're going to be covered in blood. Those were close range shots. They were, according to testimony, 3 feet basically away from he was from the victims or whoever shot them. You'd be covered in blood. You'd get back, you'd have blood everywhere. You'd have blood on your shoes. You would have to really clean up, shower. You'd have to make sure blood isn't in the house anywhere. Your feet aren't, you know, don't have blood on them. You'd have to bag up the clothes. You'd have to get the murder weapons. You'd have to get everything in the vehicle so that you weren't leaving any DNA or blood in the car also. You'd have to get Maggie's phone, make sure you got that in there. Jury question will be, was there enough time for him to do all of that? Because it is a short window, but jurors will debate that. They will deliberate on that.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: It is interesting because just watching it seems nitty-gritty from 8

utterances.speaker: ELLIOT WILLIAMS, CNN LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: You know, a little bit of both, Kate. And here's the thing, in all -- everything in criminal trials comes down to credibility. Do you believe the witness or the evidence is put before you? If you're a juror, you know, do you trust that this is the fingerprint that was at the scene of the crime? Do you trust the words that come out of this person's mouth? And let's be perfectly blunt, this is not a credible witness.Number one, he's admitted to lying to the police. Number two, there are discrepancies in his story. Number three, this whole question of, and I think it was a brilliant question were the dogs alarmed? Was there somebody else there that you, you know, you know your dogs pretty well would -- were they behaving in a manner that suggested that there might have been somebody else there? So he's got some big credibility issues. But walking through some of the things that Jean talked about a moment ago, you just don't have evidence linking him specifically to the scene of the crime, or at least it's challenging evidence. So, for instance, number one, you got no murder weapon. Number two, you don't have blood on his clothing. Number three, the number of minutes that passed. So it's just, there are some problems here on all sides. But the big thing is you have evidence linking him to the crime and it's a little tenuous at this point.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: And Elliot, I did want to ask you about that because while each piece of what he has testified to and what we're hearing in cross is very interesting and obviously it's going to add up. The basics there, there's no smoking gun, there's no murder weapon, there's no eyewitness. I continue to wonder how high the hill is to climb for the state to prove its case.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: And Jean, we've watched so many trials and you've been watching this one from the beginning. What do you think of I mean, it seems that there's real tension and frustration that is being exposed or is being played into on the part of the prosecutors as they're in this cross. The fact that we're now hearing the chief prosecutor almost with every questions talk about this new story that you're now crafting, the way that they kind of went into that and even the moment when we saw the, his defense attorney stand up and object when it came to, he said on Fifth Amendment grounds, when they were talking about that, Murdaugh was saying he'd made multiple requests to even tell his story to the prosecutors. Just what do you think of that dynamic?

utterances.speaker: CASAREZ
utterances.sentences: Well, that was fascinating right then, because it talked about -- he -- Murdaugh really started it, saying, we begged you, we wanted to talk to you and you wouldn't respond to us. And so then the prosecutor says, yes, you remain silent. You didn't say that what the truth was about the kennel. You didn't tell so and so and so and so and so and so. Well, you have a right to remain silent right, when you're a defendant. And so that's when the Fifth Amendment argue.But the judge ruled for the prosecution. And so it just kept going. What's fascinating is how it all started, this cross examination with the financial crimes, right?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: It felt like a completely different trial we're watching.

utterances.speaker: CASAREZ
utterances.sentences: Now when the jury gets the case, the verdict form is not going to have anything about the financial crimes, it is about the murders, right? In fact, there will be in the charge a statement that the financial crimes you cannot use to show he's guilty of this, but to show motive.
